column1: Before 19 June 2021, will the end-of-day closing value for the Turkish lira against the U.S. dollar exceed 9.00?
column6: ['Finance', 'Foreign Policy', 'Non-US Politics']
Need a 3.6% move in next couple days. Holding at 1%

My 8 ball says, "Don't Count on it."
It's unrealistic at the moment, but it appears the market is quite nervous ahead of the Putin-Biden summit with respects to Turkey as a NATO member country.
10% move needed over one week. No major catalysts I can think of.
time is on their side. Need a 4.5% move at some point in next 11 days. About a one standard deviation move, downgrading probability a bit but crowd still way over confident in my view
8.7305 at the time of writing. Only 3% to go and a higher close within exactly two weeks.

my forecast is still a massive outlier but now less than 5% away. Today it is reported Erdogan wants interest rate cuts which has put extra pressure on the lira. almost every month there is political interference in the finances which pushes the lira down. it is still a good bet to get to 9:1 just whether it will happen in 19 days. happy to be out there on this one...

Erdogan decision to replace the deputy CB governor had little effect on the Lira, highlighting how much bad news is already priced in the currency/

"MEPs said Turkey had distanced itself from European values and continued backsliding in the field of rule of law. They blamed Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan for his authoritarian moves. The last two years saw an unprecedented crackdown on opposition and on media, according to the report.
About a 5% move over a months time is something like a one sd negative event. That plus the potential trigger of fed taper talk is making me up my estimate to about 17%:

Erdogan going commando versus Austria, NATO. Stockmarkets's vola (VIX) up 7.5% today. Wild swings in EUR/TRY in European trading, with half an hour to go until American trading opens. It could happen this week.

Spikes that high happen 2 times a year. It's a 4-day-ish event when it happens. So we have ~90 segments a year with 2 events a year. Probability of it not happening is 89/90 in each period = 0.98888888. There are 8 of these 4-day periods left. .98888888^8 = 0.9145.
It'll likely happen, just maybe not in time...
Rethinking, near record 8.58 high, deferring interest rates not enough and bank running low on muscle (cash) to sustain this, over 100 billion dollars this experiment.

8.50TRY per USD today, time of writing. Nearly six per cent of devaluation to go, one closing day lower. +0.8% EUR/TRY after half a trading day, means within a week the question could resolve "Yes", if the crisis in Turkey escalates. Maybe the Israel/Hamas crisis, which probably hasn't seen its peak yet, will be a key factor, since there's a lot of uncertainty in the region (Turkey has an ambition of being a regional (super) power...).
Increasing on the higher than forecast US Inflation. (Bad for all emerging markets)
Dropping as the governor seems to have abandoned his plan to cut rates
Dropping on time and relative stability

Continuing to lower as time passes
Ham fisted handling of the economy has driven some to crypto land to their detriment unfortunately. Only 7 weeks on this question. What else can happen?

Hovering at 8.2. Has been up to 8.5. Only 6 weeks to go. Keeping probability high, relations with us Rocky and impacting. Endogamy due to make speech Monday. https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/turkish-lira-nears-record-low-after-cenbank-comment-us-genocide-move-2021-04-25/
Time is running out. The next monetary policy meeting is scheduled for May 6th 2021. https://www.tcmb.gov.tr/wps/wcm/connect/EN/TCMB+EN/Main+Menu/Announcements/Calendar
Lowering as time passes. 6 weeks isn't long for that big of a move. Lira will continue depreciation, all a question of timing at this point unless policy re-reverses.
just under 2 months to go and 8.23 now. needs a 9.35% further depreciation which is not out of bounds given the politicalisation of the Turkish finance system plus bitcoin/currency frauds....

The replacement of the CBRT Governor points towards weaker TRY going forward. Also as far as I understand the question if on any day the USDTRY rate exceeds 9.00 then it will count. So this is like a knock-out option.
The market appears to have stabilized from two self inflicted wounds. With the self inflictor still at large, who knows what happens next.
Reacting to governor firing / big move. Feels like it still needs something else to tip it over bit still plenty of time for that
Mkssd new governor being hired. So decreasing my jump from 70 to 25
Lira is potentially recovering from two big shocks of change in financial leadership. Will there be more?
Point gun at foot, pull trigger, then do it again.
In 3 months anything can happen!!!

I had previously misread the question. I thought it said on June 19, but in fact it’s just saying st any point before June 19 will that happen. Lira trading at 8.28, so we are just talking about a 8% move, which is about a 0.5 standard deviation event, which brings the likelihood to 31%. Added to this I was thinking about the returns in the forward market when this is really about the spot market. Just looking at the interest rate diffeeentials, the lira is discounted to fall about 15% per year. At the same time my personal view is that the current move is overdone.
~7.5% of devaluation and a daily closing left to go. Today's return in EUR/TRY: 1.4%

still circa 10% to go but given the political nature of the movements, that is no longer a stretch. There has been a huge movment to date which i had felt possible so yet another large movement would take the overall change since the beginning in to a very large devaluation so there is possibility of recovery hence less than 50% still

The Turkish Lira has weakened from around 3.0 to currently 8.08 in just 5 years. Previous moves by Erdogan to control the Central Bank and force lower interest rates have been followed by Lira weakness, just as we witness in the previous week. However, 9.00 is stil far away and a lot of bad news is already priced in the Lira. Reaching 9 would require more time time just 3 months from now, in my opinion.

Firing of the most recent central banker over increasing interest rates has thrown markets into disarray. It’s not likely to get resolved soon. Markets are spooked now because the president fired a central banker who was implementing good monetary, and he was fired it seems because the president does not believe in that monetary policy. When politicians start imposing their own views outside the experts investors lose trust which leads to volatility. Exchange rate is already over 8. 9 is going to happen.
Rethinking my view that interest cuts necessary for this to resolve yes. Some thinking 10 by end of 2021 a serious possibility.
3/26 closed above 8 to the $, things are not going to improve with the new governor, I am afraid.

Yesterday i went from 25 to 10 because lira seemed to be holding below 8. Well, that was short. Going back to 50. Thw lira could pop if the turks decide to convert npw in advance of the inevitable currency controls.
10 per cent devaluation left (currently 8.13 TRY per USD) to go... I wonder if the blockade of the Suez Channel and its impact on marine trade could further accelerate the downfall of TRY.
Coming down from 25. Looks like it has settled at 8. There is 80 days left so we are just running out the clock. Leaving 10% because turkey could lower interest rate.
The political game just starting to get hot this year and so the chances rising too
Looks like interest rate cut before June 19 unlikely, would require this for Lira to go beyond 9 in my view

The new Central Bank Governor, Sahap Kavcıoğlu, has publicly positioned himself as a man who believes low interest combats inflation (1), but has reiterated since entering office that "policy would not change any time soon and depend on inflation" (2).
Seems to be bouncing back a bit..
Hmm, gonna swing this way for a bit
Lira will be down, Turkish stocks will be down, but this may be a long slide before it hits 9 to the $ - exiting positions causes scramble for lira in short term.

recent firing of central bank boss rattled the markets and rate spiked to over 8 before settling back to 7.89 today. now only need 14% devaluation to get to 9. given the highly political nature of the hire/fire process the risk is more likely to the downside of the lira.

bne IntelliNews Editor's Picks -- TURKEY INSIGHT: Frantic defence of lira’s 8.00 line as foreign investors scramble to offload all Turkish papers It's now official: Turkey has the least attractive bonds in the world. The meltdown continues apace with investors offloading Turkish obligations in a frantic defence of the TRY8 to the dollar line that they have already lost. The central bank has already run down its reserves by some $100bn defending the currency even before the well respected Naci Agbal was sacked as governor of the central bank at the weekend.

Going to ride the next month in the safety of 25%. Which is ahead of crowd. The new governor is going to be loose with rates. There are only 2 months left on the question, so maybe lkra will not cross 9 when question closes. But it will cross this year if rates are loosened.
Fired central banker. Lira was 6.5 and shot up to 8.0. Need to get a new governor and then see if markets believe he will restrain erdogan.
from BNE - Erdogan sacks another central banker

The Turkish Lira is quickly approaching its intra-day lows in European trading of 9.52 TRY versus the EURO. Other than expected, the fault line in this type of earthquake leads along a highly politized central bank that is widely seen by politicians and the Erdogan circle as their instrument for domestic politics, and is thus incapacitated to run independent and economically sound and founded central bank policy in order to halt high and ever faster accelerating inflation. The current spike in devaluation is more than a short episode, it seems it's a blunt certificate of distrust and "vote-by-heels" against foreign investments in Turkey. The monetary situation is bad enough to start some domino effects within the country that could further spur crisis, and it could be a matter of days only now until this question resolves "YES".

The new Central bank head believes cutting interest rates will arrest inflation. I think the cooldown in the spot rates happened after the Kavicioglu clarified that there won't be any drastic measures in the near term. The next central bank meeting on 15th April will be key to watch.

It is a low probability event because the central bank has improved its policy credibility and hiked interest rates. In the global low-yield environment Turkey offers one of the highest rates of return. So this attracts foreign investors.

Since peaking at 8.5 per USD in November the Turkish lira has steadily declined to 7.27. It is unlikely that Turkey's economy will drastically weaken and the lira will spiral out of control over the next few months.
1/28 7.3075TRY/$ - not likely unless something drastic happens in the region.

current rate is 7.34 so that implies a change of 22.6% highest recently was 7.93 in october 2020. august 2019 was 5.58 so movement to current c30% but over 18 months. therefore unlikely to reach 9 particualrly as dollar is weakening.
Dropping on fall to 7.42. 20% up is about 1.25 standard deviations. Think that should be more like 10% but happy to have fat tails.

Crisis and tensions will make it go up.
1/1/21 = 7.4393TRY/$ not likely to show much change short term.

Even during the rapid drop of the Turkish lira, it took 9 months to drop 20%. Currently, at 7.38, less than 6 months to go. I don't believe Turkish lira depreciation will accelerate any further. On the contrary, I believe in reversal to the mean, i.e. the Lira will either depreciate slower or in fact will appreciate.
Highly unlikely. Turkey is one of the burgeoning economies and inflation will impact the lire.

12/29 = 7.3937TRY / $ over the last five years the Turkish lira has fallen from 2.8TRY/$ to the current value. The lowest point was Nov 6 2020 when it was about 8.5TRY/$. It has strengthened since then, under the guidance of a new finance minister (not the President's son-in-law). Currency usually moves slowly, even the Turkish lira's fall was not monotonic. While it could easily touch 8.5TRY/$ again, it will likely continue to respond to the new finance minister and not leap to 9TRY/$. Due to the short term nature of this question and honeymoon period for the new finance minister I find it doubtful it to drop to 9TRY/$.
Poorly run economy; new central bank head won't be able to make much progress and won't last long anyway.

It looks as though the rate is improving from a low of 8.52 on 8 November, so I don't see it it getting much worse in the next 6 months. Historically it has never been bad enough to hit 9.
Erdogan is playing the currency manipulation game and is not going to stop until he is out of office, there is not alternative for him if he wants to keep been the bully of the Bosphorus.

Has hit ~8,5 but that was an outlier. In 25 years has never hit 9,0 Erdogan has booted son-in-law and is displaying “some” economic sense but still possible. https://www.ft.com/content/63687cfe-fedf-4bfc-aa6f-638e41c4e874
Basing on historical trends. A key issue will become strength of the US $
I was arriving at much the same view as @erikbays myself, and so I'll just cite his sound rationale.

The Lira has been under pressure recently but so has the US dollar. I believe the dollar is at a crisis point. there's not demand for the number of treasuries US government is trying to issue. In 2020 the FED purchased more treasuries than were issued by the treasury during that time. 60 cents have been created for every dollar in circulation since March.
Dollar weakens 1H21. Lira is managed.
It would require a solid crisis, turbulent and chaotic circumstance over a few days, to trigger a devaluation of this scope.
